Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I developed a knowledge of conservation tactics.
Learned about the major conservation issues threatening our planet today and explored potential solutions through examples and case studies.
How to make a reserve
I learned about endangered species, conservational status, and protected areas. I learned about current events regarding current conservation issues.
The science of conservation as well as how policy should be designed.
very little of anything

This course is a good introduction to the field of conservation biology. Some of the topics we covered included methods for preserving biodiversity, climate change, and ocean acidification. The running theme throughout the course was human impact on the environment.
I learned about the current global challenges to conservation and why we should conserve ecosystems and species.
I learned a good deal about the subject matter and about the conservation of species.
Overview course of conservation biology. Starts with basic terminology, then moves on to talk about the main issues for conservation, and ways to mitigate these issues.

I've gained an understanding of the basics of conservation, and also got to practice communicating conservation principles in papers. There was also a debate in which we got to apply our knowledge to a current conservation challenge, and I felt that that was a really interesting way to tie in policy, conservation, and current events.
Applying greater information about conservation biology to specific species, populations, and contexts.
Not a lot of new information because I took AP Environmental Studies and the course material was very similar
I learned a lot of general conservation ideas and characteristics of animal communities and populations.
I learnt about the conflicts present in conservation biology, about different species and threats to conservation
I successfully learned how to study for exams, read graphs, understand scientific papers, and a better understanding of the world we live in.
I learned the basics of conservation biology, such as the processes that cause biodiversity loss and the methods to restore habitats. i also got better at reading scientific papers.

I learned how to understand and analyze conservation techniques from the point of view of someone not from a science background. After this course, I feel a much greater appreciation and understanding for the work of conservationists in a world that is constantly developing.
N/A
Very applicable knowledge about the current state of our planets environment and ways that we are currently combating the damage humans are doing.
Learned a lot about species protection and the things threatening biodiversity.
Learned about conservation methods for different landscapes
I gained insight into the necessity of conserving the environment. Its impact on the earth is what allows me to flow through my day so effortlessly.

Cons Bio was a really good class. TL;DR take it if you think you would like learning about cool conservation techniques and want to do less work than most classes. Don't get it twisted though, this class does take a good deal of studying. Also, you should be going to every lecture. I learned A LOT about our world and how it interacts with itself, loved it. Probably changing my major to environmental studies.

This course provided a broad overview of topics in conservation biology. I also feel that I benefitted from the emphasis on learning to read and analyze scientific papers. The readings from Kolbert's book were also illuminating and helped to bring the material to life.

We learned what conservation biology is, why we need it, and how to implement it. We learned a variety of concepts about organism, such as animal behavior, ecology, and evolution, but we also learned about the impact humans have on these organisms and ways that we can impact them.
I learned about ways to preserve the earth and the impacts of the anthropocene on species.
We learned the basics of conservation biology and about the various ways conservationists work to preserve ecosystems and populations.

Better understanding of ecological problems related to biodiversity, particularly what anthropogenic threats face biological communities. A stronger grasp of the scientific writing genre, and the ability to glean key information from research articles.

As someone interested in environmental policy, I thought this class was extremely helpful in understanding conservation methodology and how best to protect different species. I especially enjoyed the case studies and real-world applications integrated into the course. Taking this class made me rethink our current conservation philosophy and the difficulties involved in protecting species and ensuring their long-term survival.
Practical knowledge of environmental issues in our world

An amazing class geared towards policy and non-science majors. Equips you with the necessary information to go forth into the world and consider the environment and importance of conservation in all things.
I took this course because I needed a Science credit.

The structure of the content and testing is well organized and makes absorbing information easy--in some ways it feels like a high school class because of this. Some lectures feel a little bit slow but overall the relevance of the material as it applies to our world today makes the class engaging.
The lectures are not particularly engaging, but the overall topic is interesting. The textbook is straightforward and there are weekly readings that dont take too long.
exams are poorly designed, way too long, and lecture does not prepare students for them whatsoever
The course was interesting and engaging but at times it felt like the lectures were redundant, particularly in the final third of the class.

I think the strength of the course was the nature of the material and teaching. I think it could be improved with more focused readings for section (i.e. choosing to spend a day on either scientific articles or the Sixth Extinction and not both).

The course is fairly easy, although the tests can occasionally have application of concepts that have not been thoroughly explored in class. I also found that the ease of the course was actually a weakness because it made it harder to want to come to class. The course could be improved by clearer explanation of the expectations of the class.
Exams can be a bit confusing and too long for the time given. Other than that, I loved the course. Learned a lot of interesting things, liked the teacher and loved my TA.

Strengths: You get a great overview of a lot of topics in Conservation Biology, and the supplemental readings are relevant and interesting. I particularly enjoyed the class trip to the Peabody where we got to see specimens of endangered/extinct species that we may not have otherwise had the opportunity to see. 

Weaknesses: Can't really think of any! Really enjoyed this course.
Well-organized! The expectations of work were not depicted in the syllabus as they ended up to be.
The exam questions were sometimes vague and a little broad. Other than that it was a good course over all. Relevant and great for anyone trying to get a science credit

This course could be improved by making the tests more relevant to the material and less convoluted. Many times during exams I was unclear on what the question was asking and this was a hindrance to showing how well I knew the material.
There is not enough support/guidance and reinforcement from lecture to lecture. It feels as if nothing matters until the exam, and there is not much enthusiasm surrounding the teaching.
Strengths were the the teaching. Weaknesses were that the exams were too time pressured and a lot of questions required you to guess what they wanted from the answers

The strengths of this course would be the sections, I enjoyed the time in my sections and took away a lot of information from the one-v-one lessons with my TA. The weakness would probably be the lectures, not very engaging, but full of information.

The lectures could be more engaging, however they did a good job of covering introductory conservation biology. While the material was easy to grasp, tests were often worded poorly and it wasn't always clear how or what to study for a good grade.
The day to day work was very easy, but the exams would be more difficult than anticipated. I personally really liked and thrived under this kind of environment, but it may not be for everyone.
Great TAs. Professor Puth was so understanding and clearly so passionate about what she does.

Puth wasnt the best lecturer and some of the material got repetitive. I thought the way the tests were written did not line up very well with the material we learned, or the questions werent asked specifically enough for the answers they were looking for. The questions were supposed to apply the material but they were asked in a really confusing way.

It uses examples that are interesting, the guest lecturers were GREAT! The second exam was a little long, but the first and third were okay. Better job of making clearer questions, Im glad the TAs read them before hand too.
The instructor doesn't explain the application of the material, but rather surfaces through it.

Strengths: material, workload, having such a great TA, and learning cool content. 
Weaknesses: the lectures were boring when they were given, even if the material is very cool.

I think the material for the course was presented in a well-organized and clear manner. In addition, I think the usage of Kolbert's book improved my experience in the course, as I greatly enjoyed reading it. 

In terms of weaknesses, I think the workload for the course could have been spaced out better (i.e. there was one week when we had several major assignments due in succession). In addition, I think the test questions were sometimes unclear (i.e. they would ask for three categories of something when we had not discussed the course material necessarily in terms of categories).

This course was very organized, the lecture notes were posted online, and the textbook wasn't necessary if you attended lecture.  The weakness of this course was that no one asked questions during lecture and the lectures were very slow. In addition,

I like how in this class, the tests were not an incredibly large part of the grade. I also liked reading the Sixth Extinction.

I think a major weakness of the class was the tests - they were too hard because the questions were all phrased very broadly.
I feel like this course was a great first time conservation biology class. Everything we learned felt very relevant to application outside of the classroom.

Strengths: very thorough coverage of the course material, fair tests, sections TFs are very knowledgeable and effective teachers. Professor Puth is very reasonable and makes her expectations clear. A great way to get a solid grasp of how humans affect biodiversity on Earth and what we can do to mitigate negative effects. 
Weaknesses: many lectures are repetitive, I found overall student engagement to be low.

I really enjoyed the section discussions and case studies integrated into the course. I also thought the Kolbert readings were a great supplement, although I wish we would've talked about them more during discussions. I think the evaluative part of the course was fair especially since so much weight was given to discussion and the lecture write-up and position paper. However, the tests themselves were very much application-based and required not only memorizing the material but knowing how to apply it. Although I think this helped me apply what I learned, it took some time to get used to. In the future, I would recommend more example questions to become more accustomed to this type of testing.
I mean honestly I wish the powerpoint slides were more detailed so I wouldn't have had to attend every lecture, but I thought that the course was pretty straightforward.

I think professor Puth is doing the school and students an incredible favor in teaching the class. She has found the perfect balance between teaching an engaging class, teaching a class that isin't going to kill a students GPA, and making sure that students fulfill their science distribution in a meaningful way. By saying meaningful I do not just mean that they care slightly more about the environment, after this class you actually feel that you have been given the tools to think more critically about the effect things have on the environment around you, and I hope that it has made students much more responsible consumers and future policy influences. If professor Puth does not yet have tenure, she deserves it as she is really doing everyone a huge favor in teaching this course.

Its a gut. Insanely nice curve makes it impossible to not get a credit if you Credit/D the class but theres a lot of work for section so if youre going to be doing some work anyway you might as well take it for a grade. Almost everyone gets a B+ or A- based on the curve.
If you need a science credit, go for it, I guess.
There are probably easier science credits out there if that's what you're looking for but this class was well worth it.
Yes because you need a science credit
This is a good course for someone looking to fulfill a distributional requirement science credit.
Yes. I loved the topic of this course and its a good way to learn about important environmental issues in a relatively straightforward and easy manner.
Yes, very interesting course and not too difficult
no. exams are just poorly written and information is generally useless
I would recommend this course to another student. It is not a throwaway class, there is a decent amount of work involved and the material is useful.
I would recommend this course because the material is very relevant and interesting and the workload is not too high.
good science credit
It's fairly interesting and low work-load (average of 1.8 hours/week). A little bit of studying for the mid-terms and you should be good.
Yes, if the student wanted an easy science course and was somewhat interested in conservation. Otherwise, I would recommend taking something a bit more interesting.
interesting course
A good science credit for non-science majors.
Yes, great science credit for non-STEM majors. Can be a lot of work but the good part is that there are so many assignments that not a lot of weight falls on the exams.

Yes! I feel like conservation is such an important topic and people should learn about if even if their major does not directly relate. The grading system is really fair, and if you put in the work, you will do well.
If you don't have a deep background in environmental science it would be interesting and good to learn about! But if you do its a bit repetitive.
Yes, good for non-science majors looking for a science credit. Interesting material, enjoyable class.
Yes if they are interested in the material and are not very familiar with it alreadt
I would - its a fair bit of work but the content is interesting
Yes, environmental sciences is very important to have a better understanding of the world around you. Take this course if you are willing to put in the time to learn the information out of class.
I would recommend this course to a student that isn't pursuing science but is looking for a science class and has an interest in the environment.
Absolutely - I loved the topics of our discussions and I think it would be an amazing class for anyone at Yale to take, regardless of their major.
Yes, good science credit for non-science majors - not too heavy of a workload.
N/A
Yes, its very well organized and interesting in content. There are a lot of small assignments that give you lots of chances to improve.
This course was excellent - I would wholeheartedly recommend this to any student, especially those who would like to learn about the environment and bio in an accessible way.
Yes definitely. Dont need to be a science major to do well.

As an EVST major, a lot of these topics wer similar to other classes Id taken, particularly other ecology classes. But if you take this one first, then it will be a great intro into conservation. Good mix of policy and real-life examples in the lecture along side the concepts and theories.
Yes if they want to take a class that teaches them a broad picture on how the ecosystem works.

I would recommend this course to someone who does not have a background in science but is looking for an interesting science credit. The course is not too difficult and the material is actually interesting. It's also nice that there's no final, just three exams that aren't cumulative. The tests are somewhat strange because the questions are often pretty unclear, but if you actually put in the time to learn the fairly intuitive material, you should be fine.

I would only recommend this course if they are interested in the material. While concepts and terminology was new, I felt like a lot of the material that we learned in class was common sense. Therefore, I would only recommend this course if someone is very passionate about the subject, or if they are looking to fill a science requirement and this seems the most appealing way to do so.

I would not recommend this class to another student if they want a gut science credit. While the material in itself was really easy, there was a lot of work (3 tests, weekly discussion where you had to send questions to your TA in advance, 2 papers, a worksheet, and a debate). Also, the tests were really difficult because the questions were phrased very broadly - you never really knew what the question was asking. However, if you are looking to take a moderately easy science credit and have actual interest in conservation biology I would recommend it.
If you need a science credit I guess Id recommend it, but its really boring and the information is all based on hearsay. I didnt really believe a lot of what we were tested on.

I would definitely recommend this class. The material is relevant and interesting and builds on itself really well. All the readings are well picked. My section activities were good, but also majority reliant on student input, so it's really a situation where you get out what you put in. Luckily, it's a class that's definite easy to put energy into because the material is so timely.
I would recommend this course to anyone who is not a STEM major.
Yes, as a manageable science credit that is very applicable to real-world problems. The course is not fascinating, but if you pay attention you will certainly learn valuable information.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student, both as a science credit and for someone deeply interested in environmental studies or policy. Much of the information is very intuitive, so it's a good science class for someone who is not necessarily a STEM person. On the hand, even those with experience in this area will still be interested and can learn a lot through the case studies, applications, and discussion sections.
It was a science credit that was still understandable to a non-STEM major. It is also relevant to all of our lives.

I highly recommend conservation biology. You will learn things in a way that makes the distributional requirement actually seem worth it while not becoming frustrated that it is sucking your time away from things you are actually passionate about. The class treats you as you should be treated, an intelligent student who is not great at STEM but competent enough to learn the material at a reasonable pace.
